chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected rubella?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Take a history asking about:
    • Clinical features including onset and progression.
    • Risk factors for rubella infection including:
      • Contact with a person who is unwell or has had a rash in the previous 3 weeks.
      • Lack of immunity — a person is considered to be immune if they are immunocompetent and have had either two doses of MMR vaccine or laboratory evidence of prior immunity.
      • Travel to country endemic for rubella.
    • Possibility of pregnancy.
    • Past medical history (including immunosuppression) and drug history.
    • Other potential causes of symptoms.
  • Examine the person looking for clinical signs of rubella infection and complications:
    • Check vital signs including temperature.
    • Look for rash, lymphadenopathy, conjunctivitis, respiratory, musculoskeletal and neurological signs.
  • Consider the need for investigations:
    • If there is any suspicion of rubella infection, immediately notify the local Health Protection Team (HPT). Rubella is a notifiable disease.
    • Rubella cannot be accurately diagnosed through history and clinical features alone — discuss appropriate investigations urgently with a specialist.
    • It is essential to have a low threshold of suspicion for rubella in pregnant women, especially before 20 weeks' gestation. Rubella must always be excluded in pregnant women with rubella-like rash even when other causes are more likely and regardless of previous immunization history. Women who have not spent their childhood years in the UK may be at increased risk of rubella.
    • If clinically indicated, the HPT may advise investigations for parvovirus B19 and measles infection in parallel to rubella.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to assess a person with suspected rubella are based on the clinical guidelines UK Standards for Microbiology Investigations. Investigation of Pregnant Women Exposed to Non-Vesicular Rash [PHE, 2015b], Rubella [CDC, 2018] and Rubella in Pregnancy [Dontigny, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Bouthry, 2014; Bukasa, 2018].

Investigations

  • Consensus opinion in clinical guidelines [PHE, 2015b; CDC, 2018; Dontigny, 2018] and review articles [Bouthry, 2014; Bukasa, 2018] is that clinical diagnosis of rubella is unreliable as signs and symptoms of infection are non-speciﬁc — laboratory confirmation of infection is essential.
  • As rubella is a notifiable disease, all cases of suspected rubella must be discussed with the local Health Protection Team [PHE, 2010; PHE, 2016a].
  • Public Health England (PHE) guidance recommends that when rubella is suspected, pregnant women should be simultaneously investigated for immunity to both rubella and parvovirus B19 unless their immune status is already known [PHE, 2015b].
    • Parvovirus B19 can have harmful effects on the fetus, and all pregnant women with a rubella-like rash should also be tested for parvovirus B19 infection, unless they are known to be immune to parvovirus B19.
